messages.content: VanOnsAssist is a knowledgeable, friendly, and professional AI assistant for the web development company van-ons, specifically designed to help you find the right information about anything concerning the van-ons operations

What is the Van Ons Wiki primarily used for?

The Van Ons Wiki is primarily used as a centralized platform for documentation and how-to's on anything technical at Van Ons. It is constantly updated, collaborative, and encourages knowledge sharing within the team. The main topics covered include the company's way of working, code styles, tools, the WordPress Starter Theme, and a 'tips & tricks' section.
Who is allowed to add or modify content in the Van Ons Wiki?

Everyone at Van Ons has the capability to contribute to the wiki. Users can add their own wiki articles or make modifications to existing articles using the WordPress platform. However, it's essential to approach contributions with care and consideration, as existing content is written with intent and a purpose. Always confer with the author or the Tech Team if you want to make any alterations.
Can you tell me about the primary subjects in the Van Ons Wiki?

The primary subjects in the Van Ons Wiki include the company's way of working, code styles, tools, the WordPress Starter Theme, and a 'tips & tricks' section. These topics provide a comprehensive resource for technical documentation and how-to's specific to Van Ons.
What are the key areas of focus in the Van Ons Wiki?

The key areas of focus in the Van Ons Wiki are the company's way of working, code styles, tools, the WordPress Starter Theme, and a 'tips & tricks' section. These areas aim to offer a centralized and collaborative platform for technical knowledge sharing within the team.
Which aspects does the Van Ons Wiki cover in terms of technical documentation?

The Van Ons Wiki covers several aspects of technical documentation, including the company's way of working, code styles, tools, the WordPress Starter Theme, and a 'tips & tricks' section. This comprehensive resource helps team members navigate and understand various technical aspects of Van Ons' projects.
Can Van-Ons help me build an e-commerce website?

Absolutely, Van-Ons has extensive experience in building e-commerce websites using platforms such as Shopify and WooCommerce. We can help you create a unique and user-friendly online store that meets your specific needs.
What technologies does Van-Ons use for web development?

Van-Ons uses a variety of technologies for web development, including HTML, CSS, JavaScript, React, Angular, Vue.js, Node.js, and PHP. We also have expertise in content management systems such as WordPress and Drupal, as well as e-commerce platforms like Shopify and WooCommerce.
Can Van-Ons help me with website maintenance and support?

Yes, Van-Ons offers website maintenance and support services to ensure that your website stays up-to-date and runs smoothly. We can help you with content updates, plugin and software updates, security monitoring, and performance optimization.
What should I do if I'm working on an older project with a different code style?

When working on an older project with a different code style, it's important to adapt your style to the project rather than refactoring the whole project. For example, if all methods are declared using snake_case, apply that to your new code as well. This helps maintain consistency and avoid confusion.
Do I need to memorize all the guidelines?

No, there's no need to memorize all the guidelines. Most of them will already be the default when working with our current WordPress Starter Theme or a Laravel project. Use the guidelines as a reference guide for when in doubt, or in the event of a discussion with coworkers. Some of the guides could be interpreted as a matter of taste, and this rulebook helps remove the personal taste and makes things clear and concise.
What if I want to suggest changes to the guidelines?

If you think some code styles could be better, feel free to suggest changes! We move with developments in our respective expertise communities and update these guidelines from time to time. Any suggestions can be discussed with the development team via Slack, the weekly stand-up, or the Dev.Monthly sessions.
What are the syntax and formatting rules you follow?
We use 4 space indents, single quotes, keep leading zeros, remove trailing zeros, remove units from zero values, a space after colons.
How do you order CSS declarations?
Group related properties, like positioning and typography. Apply some logic that is quick to understand.
What naming conventions do you use?
We follow the BEM methodology - Block, Element, Modifier. Blocks are components, elements are parts of a block, and modifiers define variations.
When do you nest selectors?
We avoid nesting selectors, except for pseudo-classes/elements. Nesting can cause long selectors, make code less readable, and lose context.
What are the rules for typing properties and methods?
Type properties and method signatures whenever possible instead of using docblocks. Don't do type checks if you can use parameter type hinting.
When should I use nullable and void types?
Use the nullable ?type notation instead of type|null unions. Use void return type when a method returns nothing.
What about constructor property promotion?
Use it if all properties can be promoted, put each on its own line with a comma after the last one.
What are the rules for traits and strings?
Put each trait import on its own line. Prefer string interpolation over concatenation where possible.
How do you format if statements?
Always use brackets. Put unhappy path first. Avoid else with early returns and ternaries. Separate compound conditions into individual if checks.
What general skills should I learn?
Learn Git, GitHub, HTTP, HTML, SQL databases, and basic PHP.
What PHP and Laravel topics are most important?
Focus on PHP basics, OOP, Laravel routing, views, databases, relationships, authentication, APIs, testing, dependency injection.
What about WordPress backend development?
Learn WordPress theme structure, template hierarchy, hooks, custom post types and fields, caching, and ACF blocks.
What is the workflow when starting on a ticket?
Pick a ticket, understand it, create a feature branch, make changes, commit/push, open a PR, get it reviewed/tested, make any fixes, then it gets approved.
What if a ticket is missing details?
Supplement it yourself using design, docs, asking PMs/colleagues/client. Add details so changes can be properly tested.
How do you handle new projects with initial setup?
Use a general feature/JIR-1 branch for foundational tickets at first. Later switch to ticket branches once project is established.
What is the step-by-step workflow when starting work on a new ticket?

1. Pick a ticket from JIRA to work on. 2. Make sure you understand what needs to be done. 3. Create a feature branch named after ticket. 4. Make your code changes locally. 5. Commit and push changes to remote branch. 6. Open pull request to master. 7. Wait for colleague review. 8. Make any fixes requested during review.
What should I do if important details are missing from a JIRA ticket?

You should try to fill in missing details yourself by checking design mockups, technical documentation, asking PMs, colleagues or clients. Add enough so that a reviewer can properly test your changes.
Who has the final say on approving or rejecting my changes?
Typically a colleague will review first and may approve or request changes. After that, sometimes the client may also review and give final approval to close out the ticket.
How do you handle the initial setup in new projects without clear tickets?
Use a general feature/JIR-1 branch for foundational components at first without ticket branches. Later when project matures, switch to creating ticket branches for new features.
What are the steps to create a new Laravel site in Forge?

1. Login to Forge and go to Servers page. 2. Click New Site and fill in name, domain, web directory. 3. Click Add Site. 4. Go to Git Repository tab and connect to Buddy repo. 5. Adjust branch name if needed.
How do I point the site to my project code?
Connect to the Git repository in Buddy that contains your project code. Forge will deploy from that repo.
What about securing the development environment?
Go to the Security tab and create a username/password credential for access. E.g. username: vanonsklant, password: cowlabs.
What are the steps to create a new Laravel project in Rootnet?

1. Go to Projecten and click New Project. 2. Give project a name and select the Laravel template. 3. Add correct domain(s) under Domain Names. 4. Give developer access under Access. 5. Allow GitHub access under Deployment Tools.
How do I connect the GitHub repo to Rootnet?
Use GitHub Whisperer to setup Production secrets with Rootnet hostname/username. Copy Public key to SSH keys in Rootnet.
What about setting up the database?
Add database/Redis credentials from Rootnet mail to 1Password. FTP to server and create .env file with credentials. Set DB_*, REDIS_* keys.
How do I deploy and run the site?
Run the GitHub production deploy workflow. Optionally start Horizon and setup repeating Cron tasks.
How are WordPress updates organized across the development team?

Sites are strategically assigned to developers based on their knowledge, either built it or know it well. Everyone has a bundle of sites to be responsible for updating. Time is planned every 2 weeks for all developers to execute updates.
What should I do to prepare before starting the actual update process?
Review the site beforehand - check email settings, recipients for automated mails, backups. Test all updates first on the development environment before touching production.
Can you walk me through the full process of updating a site?

Use ManageWP to update WP core, plugins, themes. Go through each category methodically. Review changelogs before updating. After updating test site functionality thoroughly on dev, both front and backend. Check common and client-specific features. Fix any issues before continuing with next site.
What extra precautions should I take when updating sites?

No emails should be sent to clients during testing. Watch for complete site failure, restore from backup if needed but keep control, don't fully restore. For ACF, upload plugin first before removing from theme. Keep PHP versions up-to-date.
When should I consider updating a Laravel application?
Always apply security updates when available. For major version updates to Laravel, Statamic etc, consider if still actively working on project or if it will stop receiving security fixes.
What is the process for applying security updates?
Run composer update. Composer will find updated packages with non-breaking changes automatically. But you still need to thoroughly test application afterwards.
How do I update to a new major version of Laravel?
Use official upgrade guides provided with each release. Can also use Laravel Shift to automatically handle changes, but discuss with team first as it costs per project.
What kind of things should I test after any updates?
Test all critical functionality - forms, auth, APIs, workflows etc. Check logs for errors. Confirm no unintended emails were sent to clients during testing.
What are some good general use packages for Laravel?
For roles/permissions use spatie/laravel-permission. For multilingual models use spatie/laravel-translatable. For media management use spatie/laravel-medialibrary.
What packages help with SEO in Laravel projects?
Use diglactic/laravel-breadcrumbs for breadcrumbs. Use our vop-seo package for SEO tags. Use spatie/laravel-sitemap for sitemaps. Use spatie/schema-org for schema.org markup.
What are some useful packages related to Nova?
For media library use ebess/advanced-nova-media-library. For slugs use spatie/laravel-sluggable if not using Nova. For tags use spatie/nova-tags-field. For settings use optimistdigital/nova-settings.
How should I approach writing a TD for a Laravel project?
Identify all user actions needed. Break down high level goals into detailed steps and sub-tasks. Document every feature, field, button at granular level - nothing is obvious.
What are some examples of functionality to document?
Admin dashboard capabilities, menu systems, content models, SEO fields, forms required, media library setup, analytics/data tracking needs, frontend technical considerations, hosting environment.
What scaffolding can help accelerate development?
The Laravel Starter Kit provides frontend scaffolding - Webpack, SASS, SVG sprites, responsive images. Integrates well with Spatie media library. Helps avoid refactoring later.
What special hosting considerations are there?
Laravel hosting needs more advanced configuration - PHP versions, Redis, Supervisor, Buddy pipelines. Cloudflare can help with caching needs. Plan this with hosting provider upfront.
How can I output variables in Blade?
Use {{ $var }} to output a variable, automatically escaping HTML. Use {!! $var !!} to output without escaping HTML.
What Blade statements are useful for control flow?
Use @if, @else, @elseif, @foreach, @forelse, @for, @while, @unless for conditionals and loops. @isset, @empty can conditionally render blocks.
How do I work with template inheritance and sections?
Use @extends to inherit a layout. @section and @yield define content blocks. @stack with @push/@prepend allows multiple content blocks in one section.
When should I use PHP tags?
@php and @endphp allow writing PHP logic, but should be avoided if possible. Inline PHP is allowed outside these tags.
How do I create and use an anonymous Blade component?
Save component markup to a blade file like views/components/card.blade.php. Render with <x-card> element in any template, access attributes as variables.
When should I create a component class instead?
Create a Component class when you need control over data passed to the template, or have a lot of logic that doesn't belong in the template directly.
How do I pass data from the class to the template?
Define public properties in the class to pass data. Render a custom view with data instead of the default in render() method.
How do I register a new custom post type?
Create a class extending BasePost, use Registers trait. Add class to post_types config. Override methods to customize labels, slug etc.
How can I add ACF fields to a custom post type?
Use the HasFields trait. Define fields in getFields() method, returning ACF arrays. Location is automatically set.
How do I display custom post data in my templates?
Use the HasTemplateTags trait methods instead of WordPress functions. Custom logic can be added as non-static methods on the class.
How can I run a custom query for my post type?
Call static ::query() method with a WP_Query argument array. Returns a PostCollection for easier processing.
How do I register a new taxonomy?
Create a Taxonomy class, use Registers trait. Set $taxonomy property, linked post types. Override methods to customize labels, slug etc.
Can I add ACF fields to a taxonomy?
Yes, use the HasFields trait. Define fields in getFields() method, returning ACF arrays. Location is automatically set.
How do I access taxonomy data in my code?
Term instances have a getMeta() method for metadata. Add custom non-static methods on the taxonomy class for more complex needs.
What are some examples of view files I might create?
View files like parts/header.blade.php, pages/home.blade.php, partials/event-item.blade.php. Typically organize by site section and component.
When rendering a view, can I pass multiple variables?
Yes, the second argument when rendering a view is an associative array. Define multiple key/value pairs to pass many variables.
What if I want to render a view inside another view?
Use the @include Blade directive inside a view to render another view, just like voView() in PHP code.
How can I check if a view file exists before rendering?
Use the ViewFinder: $finder = new ViewFinder; $finder->exists('pages.home'); Returns true if view exists.
How do I create a controller for a default template file?
Name it like the file, Single{PostType}Controller. Extend TemplateController, add handle() method to render views.
What about controllers for custom page templates?
Same idea but in page-templates folder. Add template comment to specify name. Extend TemplateController and handle rendering.
How does dependency injection work in controllers?
Add type-hinted arguments to handle() method, they will auto resolve to post, term, collection objects etc.
How do I create a basic GitHub workflow?
Workflows are YAML files. Define name and triggers under on. Add jobs with runs-on, steps for actions like checkout, install, test, build.
How can I manually trigger a workflow execution?
Add a workflow_dispatch trigger. Then run workflow manually from the Actions tab. Useful for testing one-off executions.
What are some more advanced GitHub workflow features?
Use env variables to avoid repetition. Add secrets for credentials. Chain jobs with needs. Share artifacts between jobs. See GitHub docs for more.
What is included in the quotation checklist for 2023?

The quotation checklist for 2023 includes considerations such as whether there is test time in the quotation, which should be 15% of the Tech Phase, at €85 per hour. It also includes whether time to guide the launch is included, what falls under content migration, who is responsible for redirects, and whether each line has a time estimate that matches the description and quantity.
What are the rules for new business?

The rate for Laravel and WordPress development work is €110 per hour excluding VAT. The rate in 2019 was €100 per hour, and before that, it was €85 per hour. Testing is +15% of the Technical Phase, and project management is +10% of the subtotal. Design and content can be offered for €85 per hour. Conversations with prospects (new business) are preferably done with two PMs. Always make a written delineation of the project.
What should I avoid in the new business conversation?

Avoid speaking about 'new sales' or 'new business'. We are there for the customer, not for our business. Preferably do not show the Technical Document, unless the customer asks for it. Let each other finish speaking and do not repeat stories that the other has just told. Never criticize the proposal.
What are sprints?
The post-2019 method of estimation consists of sprints. A sprint is always 2 weeks. With the hourly rate of €110, 1 sprint then costs €8,800 excluding VAT.
What is a standard site?

A standard site is one that doesn't require technology that deviates significantly from WordPress and needs fewer than 10 unique templates. A Technical Document can be created in a few days (paid) or for free as part of the quotation. Up to 8 templates development can be done in 1 sprint (€8,000), but it's better to have extra days for testing and delivery (12 days, €12,000). Design can be done in a few additional days or in 2 sprints (4 weeks, €16,000).
What is an example of a shop?

An example of a shop ideally stays as close as possible to the WooCommerce flow: product overview > product single > shopping cart > checkout. Payment is done via Mollie, and other systems are usually more challenging. A shop without a shopping cart is not a shop, and we can work with Gravity Forms. A shop with a few other types of pages requires at least 2 sprints of development work (€16,000) due to settings. Design can be done in 1 (internal) or 2 (external) weeks.
What is an example of a Standard + Shop + NASA site?

A Standard + Shop + NASA site has 10+ templates for the site itself, the shop flow, and a connection with system X. It requires a minimum of 2 weeks (€8,000) for design and a minimum of 6 weeks (€24,000) for development. For an unknown connection, we often use 'from €10,000' depending on the API documentation. Creating a connection is only possible if an API is available for all involved software.
What is an example of taking over an existing site?

Taking over an existing site requires a minimum of 1 week to receive data, set up the development environment, and assess the site's status. Involve the Technical Lead. We can never know if it's a good fit without a copy or FTP access. Only take over with the intention of building a new site or providing ongoing maintenance. Taking over hosting alone doesn't make sense.
What makes a customer an interesting lead?

A customer is an interesting lead if they can spend at least EUR 4,000 on design, their deadline can be met, they can meet our payment terms, and they are willing to pay for PM hours and a paid preliminary process.
What are some red flags to look out for before negotiations?
Red flags include requests coming from a private address, the customer using technical terms incorrectly, and a very tight deadline. These can indicate that the lead may not be a good fit.
What are some red flags to look out for during negotiations?

During negotiations, be wary if the customer uses many technical terms almost correctly, promises more business if the first project is done at a good price, or uses the word 'quotation' when the details are not yet 100% certain. These can indicate potential issues down the line.
What are some red flags to look out for during and just before kickoff?

During and just before kickoff, red flags include the customer missing payment terms, paying bills from an account other than the company's account, and not delivering designs on time or delivering designs with new functionality. These can indicate potential issues with the project.
Where do you prefer to host websites?

Since 2023, we prefer to host websites at Rootnet, where both Laravel and WordPress sites can be hosted. Savvii is also still in use for WordPress. In the past, we used Kinsta, Cloud.nl, and True, but this has been phased out since 2023.
Do you provide email hosting?

No, we do not provide email hosting. Gmail and Office 365 are fantastic options. We can help with setting up Gmail, but not with Office 365. None of our servers contain mail software, as it makes hosting more business-critical due to privacy, sensitive information, and potential email loss.
What are the hosting prices?

As of May 2023, our hosting prices are as follows: Shared hosting at €150 per month, Dedicated VPS with various configurations ranging from €300 to €550 per month. All prices include WordPress and plugin updates, access to our support channel, and are exclusive of VAT. Hosting contracts are only for 6 or 12 months.
What other services do you offer?

We offer domain registration, SSL certificates, Extended Validation (EV) certificates, Wildcard certificates, and extended SLAs for shorter response times. Domain registration can be done at TransIP or Versio. SSL certificates can be obtained for free with Let's Encrypt.
What kind of support do you provide?

Hosting always comes with maintenance, including updates and support, as we are obligated to ensure the sites are safe and up-to-date. We provide support for hosting-related issues and can help with recurring invoices and handling late payments.
What are the style rules for invoices?

Style rules for invoices include providing a clear description of the work, explaining the 'units' such as hours, writing months without capital letters, having a clear title, specifying if it's a down payment or final payment, and avoiding lines with a '0.0' amount. Discounts should be mentioned in a separate line with a reason.
How do you handle invoicing for new customers?

For new customers, we require a 50% down payment before starting the project. We wait until the down payment is received before starting the project. This rule applies to all new customers, regardless of any prior relationship. Communicate this to the customer so they understand the process.
How do you handle invoicing for existing customers?

For existing customers with a good payment history, you can be more flexible with the down payment requirement, but it's still preferable to follow the same process as for new customers. Existing customers are those who have made previous payments without issues.
What about interim invoices?
You can issue interim invoices, for example, invoicing 30% when the project is 80% complete. This can be done if you anticipate problems or feel it's necessary for a particular customer.
What is the policy for starting new projects or features?

A customer can start a new project or feature only after all outstanding invoices related to previous projects or features have been paid. For customers with a poor payment history, development will only start if everything is paid 100% upfront.
What is the 10% Project Management fee?

Since 2019, we add a standard 10% project management fee to every invoice, based on the subtotal. This fee covers the project manager's role as the main point of contact and the person responsible for the entire project's delivery. The fee is not applied to hosting costs.
What is the process for creating recurring invoices?
You should create these types of invoices as soon as you bill for something like the hosting of a project. This prevents administrative errors.
What settings should I pay attention to?

Pay attention to the 'First Issue Date'. If you're billing the final invoice (50%) of a new website plus the hosting, then the First Issue Date of the recurring invoice is 1 year later. Also, set 'On Scheduled Date' to 'Automatically send this invoice'. The sender should ideally be 'administratie@van-ons.nl' so that any customer responses can be handled by the administration.
What should be the subject of the invoice?

The subject of the invoice should be consistent and easily recognizable. Make sure the site name/URL is included, not the company name as it often differs from how we know the customer/site. For hosting, we do something like: 'Van Ons Webhosting - www.snippetmedia.nl' or 'Van Ons Dedicated Webhosting - www.aureus.nl'.
What is the standard text for a Shared hosting invoice?
The standard text for a Shared hosting invoice can be found at this link: https://vanons.harvestapp.com/recurring_invoices/247119/edit
What about the standard text for a Dedicated hosting invoice?
The standard text for a Dedicated hosting invoice can be found at this link: https://vanons.harvestapp.com/recurring_invoices/283337/edit
What can be added to a hosting quote?

You can add that with good hosting, we ensure a safe, reliable, fast website. Hosting is about the storage of the site, the place on the internet where it stands. With us, access to our Support channel and periodic, human-checked updates are included. We handle minor defects that arise or questions about WordPress for free. Below are all the technical details.
Why is the 'Strippenkaart' not preferred?

There are several reasons. Firstly, while we do take money now, it's deferred revenue/work because we don't immediately perform the work. Secondly, the customer can expect work from us at a later time when we may not have the capacity or room in the schedule. Thirdly, the hourly rate is fixed in the 'Strippenkaart'. Lastly, it's difficult to always precisely indicate how many hours something costs and therefore hard to stay within the limit of the 'Strippenkaart'.
What should always be on the invoice for a 'Strippenkaart'?

The invoice should always indicate what the hours can be used for (customer name or URL) and for which type of work. It should also specify how notifications should be made and how quickly our response time is following a notification/ticket. Lastly, it should state until when the hours can be used and what happens to them after that period (they expire).
Can you provide an example text for the 'Strippenkaart'?

Sure, here's an example: '1. Hours to be used for work on {customer name}. We make no distinction in the type of work (optimization, SEO, bugs, content, etc.). 2. Notifications should be made via support@van-ons.nl. Our Support Team can then indicate when these will be scheduled. 3. This 'Strippenkaart' expires on December 31, 2020, the hours that may be unused will then expire.'
What is the ideal new build project process at Van-Ons?
The ideal new build project process at Van-Ons starts with meeting the client and adding the deal to Pipedrive.
What happens after the deal is added to Pipedrive?
We then create a quote in Google Doc format, which is checked with developers and the technical lead. We also discuss payment terms with the client and get their approval on the quote.
What's the next step after getting client approval on the quote?
We start the technical document and involve developers and other colleagues as needed. We then get client approval on the technical document.
What happens after the client approves the technical document?
We kick off with developers to convert the technical document into Jira tickets. Then, we start the design and development process.
What's the process for testing and delivery?
We conduct internal tests before delivery. After testing, we deliver to the client and test together. We also make room for progressive insight if needed.
What happens after the project is delivered to the client?
We send the final payment invoice and go live. After going live, there is a meeting within 1-2 months to discuss how things are going and what the client expects in this post-live period.
What about the ideal development project process?

The ideal development project process at Van-Ons involves the client understanding what development entails, reserving enough time at Van-Ons for support, inspiration, and suggestions for improving online channels and achieving goals.
How do you keep track of the work in development projects?
Work is clearly stated in Jira to keep projects transferable and transparent. This helps us and the client stay on the same page about the project's progress.
What's the billing process for development projects?
Billing occurs monthly, at the end of the month. We ensure that all financial aspects are clear and transparent.
What about testing and deployment in development projects?
Before deploying, internal testing is conducted. There are clear agreements on how often deployments can occur per period.
What happens when a client relationship ends at Van-Ons?
When clients indicate they want to switch to a new web agency, we are helpful in the transition. It's often useful and necessary to involve Tom to go through all the steps.
What is the checklist to follow when a client relationship ends?

The checklist includes ensuring the billing is in order, checking if hosting contracts can be cancelled up to one month before the end of the current period, and removing the client from Lastpass, Google Drive, Jira, and other services exclusively used for this client.
What should be checked before ending the client relationship?

Before ending the relationship, it's important to check if all outstanding invoices have been paid, if there are any invoices that need to be sent before the collaboration can be terminated, and if we have ongoing contracts on plugins or other services exclusively for this client. All finances should be settled before starting the final tasks.
What is the process for transferring services when a client relationship ends?

The end date of our collaboration should be specified so we can plan accordingly. We need to understand what kind of transfer the client expects. Are we providing a complete backup or is another web agency involved that will do the necessary work?
What is the cooling-off period when a client relationship ends?

If the site is on a server shared with other clients, it's fine to let the departing client stay there for a while after the agreed date. This allows them to access any data they might still need. It's important to set a definitive date for when the client's data can be permanently removed. This should be noted in the Google calendar, and after about 3 months, all project data can be removed from Google Drive and the user(s) can be removed from Jira.
What happens in the weekly meeting at Van-Ons?

In the weekly meeting, the PMs, Operations Manager, and Robert come together to discuss the most important topics for the entire agency. They also look at the sales and revenue figures from the previous week to keep a finger on the pulse and adjust where necessary.
What is the preparation process for the meeting?

Most data in Teamleader is automated, except for the weekly Payability and the total amount of outstanding quotes according to Pipedrive. The Payability needs to be checked as it depends on the hours everyone in the agency writes. The capacity and worked hours of each person are checked and adjusted if necessary.
What is the process if the capacity and worked hours do not match?

If the capacity is higher than the worked hours, it's checked in Forecast if someone was free or sick. If so, the number of hours can be corrected in WordPress. If someone was not free, they probably forgot to write hours. In this case, they are asked to write the correct number of hours.
What is the process for checking the outstanding quotes in Pipedrive?
In Pipedrive, the filter is set to 'Deals open less than 2 months' to see all current quotes in one column. The highest amount is noted.
What is the agenda for the meeting?

The meeting starts with checking the minutes from the previous meeting. Then, the figures in Teamleader are reviewed, including the revenue from the previous week, the Payability from the previous week, and the revenue interim score for the current year. The non-payable items are checked, and a quick look is taken at the debtors. The status of outstanding proposals from Pipedrive is also reviewed, and new points that come to the table are noted.
How do I log in to Buddy?
You can log in to Buddy by visiting the workspace URL: https://app.buddy.works/vanons. Use your own email address and password to log in.
How do I add a project in Buddy?

To add a project in Buddy, go to the dashboard and click on 'New project'. Choose 'Buddy Git Hosting' under Select GIT hosting provider and enter your project name under Name your project. Click on 'Create new project'. The project is now created and you can see the repository URL on the screen.
What is a pipeline in Buddy and how do I add one?

A pipeline in Buddy is a series of commands that are executed when a certain action is performed. In this context, it's about deploying code. To add a pipeline, go to the project where you want to add a pipeline, click on 'Pipelines' in the menu, and then click on 'Add a new pipeline' on the right side. Fill in the required fields and click on 'Add a new pipeline'.
How do I add an action to a pipeline in Buddy?

To add an action to a pipeline in Buddy, go to the pipeline where you want to add an action and click on 'Add the first action' under 'Actions'. Choose SFTP or FTP, fill in the (S)FTP details and the root folder of the website on the server in Remote path, and click on 'Add this action'. Now the pipeline with action is set up and can be deployed.
How do I deploy a project using Buddy?

To deploy a project in Buddy, go to the project you want to deploy, click on the 'Pipelines' tab, and click on 'Run' for the server you want to deploy to. Optionally, add a comment and click on 'Run now'. The deployment will be executed.
How do I deploy to all servers simultaneously in Buddy?

To deploy to all servers simultaneously in Buddy, go to the 'Pipelines' tab of the project, click on 'Execute all pipelines' in the right menu, and confirm the action by clicking on 'Continue'. All pipelines will be executed.
How do I deploy to a specific branch in Buddy?

To deploy to a specific branch in Buddy, go to the 'Pipelines' tab of the project, click on the current branch name under 'Branch' for the server you want to deploy to, choose the branch you want to deploy from the dropdown, and click on 'Run'. Optionally, add a comment and click on 'Run now'. The deployment will be executed. Don't forget to switch back to the original branch when you're done testing.
How do I undo a deployment in Buddy?

To undo a deployment in Buddy, go to the 'Pipelines' tab of the project, click on 'Run' for the server you want to revert, and in the screen that appears, choose the commit you want to deploy under 'Revision'. Click on 'Run now', and the deployment will be executed.
What is the first step to add a website via RunCloud?
The first step is to select the desired server where you want to add the website. For example, you can choose the newest server like DEV6 and click on 'View'.
How do I create a web application in RunCloud?

In the left menu, click on 'Web Application' and then on the 'Create Web App' button. Fill in the project name at 'Web application name', the URL at 'Domain name', and select the desired PHP version and 'Web application stack'. For 'Stack mode', choose 'Development'. Do not change the other fields.
How do I create and link a database in RunCloud?

In the left menu, click on 'Database' and then on the 'Create Database' button. Fill in the database name and choose 'utf8mb4_general_ci' for 'Collation'. To link the database to a user, click on 'Attach user' next to the database you added and select 'dev6_user' for 'Database user'.
How do I activate SSL in RunCloud?
In the left menu, click on 'Web Application' and then on your project name. Then click on 'SSL/TLS' in the left menu. The default settings are usually correct, so you just need to click on 'Submit'.
Can I install WordPress via RunCloud?

Yes, you can automatically install WordPress via RunCloud. In the left menu, go to 'Web Application' and click on your project name. Then go to 'Script installer', select 'WordPress' for the script, and click on install. WordPress will be installed on your website within a few seconds.
How do I make an SFTP connection via RunCloud?

For DEV5 websites via RunCloud, there is a single SFTP account. You can find the details in the RunCloud (DEV5+) in LastPass. The only thing you need to change in PHP Storm is the root path, which you can find in RunCloud by going to 'Web application' in the left menu after clicking on the server, and then clicking on the project name.
How do I activate Let's Encrypt SSL via RunCloud?

In RunCloud, go to 'Web application' in the left menu after clicking on the server, then click on the project name. Finally, click on 'SSL/TLS' in the left menu. The only thing you need to change is the 'Let's Encrypt Environment'. Choose 'Live' to get a real certificate. You can also choose a staging certificate, but your browser will initially warn you that the certificate is not valid.
How do I whitelist an IP in RunCloud?

After logging in to RunCloud, click on the server for which you want to whitelist an IP. Then click on 'Security' in the left menu. Click on 'Add rule' at the top right to add a rule to the firewall. Choose 'Rich Rule' for Type, fill in the port (for example, port 22 for SFTP with Buddy), and fill in the IP address or IP range. Then click on 'Save'.
Are there any upcoming features in RunCloud?
Currently, you cannot specify a name or whitelist based on DNS source in RunCloud. However, RunCloud has these features on their roadmap. The exact release date is not known yet.
What about Buddy IP addresses?

All known Buddy IP addresses have been whitelisted in RunCloud to ensure smooth deployment to DEV5+. If new IP addresses are added, you can check them here: https://buddy.works/knowledge/deployments/what-are-buddy-ip-addresses
Are all websites on Runcloud DEV servers password protected?
Yes, all websites on our Runcloud DEV servers are password protected. This is achieved with custom scripts and config, as Runcloud does not provide this service yet.
How does the password protection work?

A cronjob has been set up using the Runcloud interface for all DEV servers. This script runs every 5 minutes and checks all nginx config files. For each website, an extra config file is created if it doesn't exist yet. This new config file includes another file that contains the authentication details. All visitors will be prompted to fill in the login first, unless they are in the IP whitelist.
What does the new config file contain?

The new config file contains the line 'include /etc/nginx-rc/vo-scripts/auth_basic.conf;'. The included file contains the authentication details and the IP whitelist. All visitors will be prompted to fill in the login first, unless their IP is in the whitelist.
Where are the username and password stored?
The username and password are stored in the /etc/nginx-rc/conf.d/.htpasswd file.
What should I note when working with these files?
You need to login on SSH as root in order to make changes to these files. Also, after creating a new application in Runcloud, it may take up to 5 minutes before the password protection works.
What is the Starter Theme?

The Starter Theme is the Van Ons boilerplate for a WordPress theme. It contains everything needed to build a WordPress theme and standardizes the way themes are created, making it easier for colleagues to work on each other's projects.
What does the Starter Theme do?

The Starter Theme includes tools to speed up and standardize the development process. It comes with packages to compile and generate CSS and Javascript, auto-installs libraries and packages needed for WordPress themes, and provides a pre-defined structure for CSS, Javascript, and PHP files.
Where can I find the Starter Theme?

You can find the latest version of the Starter Theme in Buddy: https://app.buddy.works/vanons/starter-theme. There, you can switch between different versions and download the files to your new project folder.
How do I install the Starter Theme?

After downloading the Starter Theme, check the installation steps in the README.md file located in the root folder. The installation process may change with each update, so the README.md file will always contain the most up-to-date information.
How can I contribute to the Starter Theme?

To contribute, commit your changes to a feature branch and notify the Tech Team via Slack or email (techteam@van-ons.nl). Once your commit is approved, it will be merged into the master branch and published as a new release.
What is the auto deploying and compiling feature in the Starter Theme?

Since version 2.3.0, the Starter Theme includes a Buddy configuration file called buddy.yml. This file creates two pipelines for auto deploying and compiling: one for DEV5 and one for LIVE (Savvii). The DEV5 pipeline deploys automatically when a new commit is pushed to the develop branch, while the LIVE pipeline is set to manual deploy. This feature eliminates the need for manual compiling and uploading for projects using Starter Theme >= v2.3.0.
How do I update the Starter Theme?

Updates to the Starter Theme should be combined into a single update whenever possible. Each feature should be developed in a separate branch, then merged to the develop branch for testing, and finally merged to master.
How should I test the changes to the Starter Theme?
You should always test the changes to the Starter Theme. You can use one of the DEV servers to do this, or check LastPass if there is already a Starter Theme test site available on the DEV servers.
How do I change the version number?

The Starter Theme uses a basic form of semantic numbering for its versioning. For patches, hotfixes, and minor changes, increment the last digit. For minor updates, increment the second digit. For major updates, increment the first digit.
How do I tag the version in GIT?
After merging to master, create a new tag in the GIT repository. This tag should contain the new version number, starting with the letter v. Also, push the tag to origin to make it visible to others.
How do I update the changelog?
The Starter Theme changelog is located at our intranet. Update it after creating a new version, including the version number and a description of all changes made.
How do I inform the team about the update?

After all updates have been made, inform the team about the update and the new version number. This can be done with a message on the intranet. For bigger changes, a presentation or even a workshop may be needed.
How do I add customers to Jira with access only to their project?

First, go to the Users overview at https://vanons.atlassian.net/admin/users. Click on the blue 'Invite user' button at the top right. Fill in the email address, username, and full name. Uncheck the 'self sign-up' option that appears when you click on 'Invite user'. Then, in the Users overview, go to the specific, newly added person by clicking on their name. Add them to the 'jira-clients' group by clicking on 'Add group' on the right side of the screen. Then remove them from the 'jira-users' group by clicking on 'Remove group'. Finally, in the project itself, go to 'Project settings', then 'People', and add the person with the role 'Clients'.
What permissions do customers have as jira-clients?

Customers as jira-clients have the following permissions: Add Comments, Assignable Users, Browse Projects, Close Issues, Create Attachments, Create Issues, Delete Own Attachments, Delete Issues, Delete Own Comments, Edit Issues, Link Issues, Move Issues, Resolve Issues, Schedule Issues, Transition Issues, Work On Issues, Manage Sprints, and Browse Users.
When should I debug?
Debugging is needed when a bug or issue arises. This can be anything from a site going down with a 500 error to a client who cannot access their WordPress.
What are some guidelines for effective debugging?

1. Make sure you fully understand the issue. Ask and re-ask what the precise issue is and ensure you are working on the right problem. 2. Never spend more than 1.5 hours on a single issue unless you are getting closer to the problem or solution. 3. After 1.5 hours, stop, take a breath, and talk to a colleague about the problem (rubber ducking). 4. Talk to a Project Manager to decide on the ideal next steps.
What should I do before starting to debug?

Take a deep breath and realize that this could take a while. Also, remember that there will always be a solution to the issue at hand, and if you don't know it yet, a colleague probably does. No matter what, the issue will be solved.
How do I determine the location of the issue?

Ask yourself the following questions: 1. What is the issue precisely? 2. How did it work previously? 3. What does this functionality depend on? 4. Does the issue involve WordPress core functionality, the theme, a plugin, or hosting/caching on different levels (server-side or application-side)?
What are the next steps after identifying the issue?

1. Find the issue. 2. Solve the issue. 3. Report back to the client or ask your Support colleague to pick up communications. If it takes more than 1.5 hours to solve the issue, keep the client in the loop, even if you have nothing new to report. Check in with the client, preferably by phone, as new information might arise and they will appreciate your status update.
What is the purpose of the Van Ons VPN server?

The Van Ons VPN server allows you to gain remote access to servers, APIs, and other services that use an IP whitelist. This means you can work securely from any location, as your internet will be effectively routed via the Van Ons HQ.
How do I use the VPN?

You can use the VPN by downloading the Wireguard client app for your device. After installation, you can import your personal configuration file, which can be provided by either Tom or Dennis. Once imported, you can enable the VPN tunnel and start using it.
What if I have issues connecting to the VPN?
If you're unable to connect to the VPN, please let us know on Slack and we'll assist you. Don't panic, we're here to help.
Can I share my VPN configuration file with others?
No, the VPN configuration files are personal. This is to ensure security and allow us to cutoff a user if necessary. Please do not share your configuration with others.
How can I access the company's book collection?
You can access the company's book collection through the Google Drive folder named 'Books'. All books purchased within the company are uploaded there for everyone's benefit.
Can I purchase books for work?

Yes, you are encouraged to purchase books that you think will be educational or helpful in your work. If the price is significantly higher than what's considered reasonable, check with Jeffrey or Robert before purchasing. Remember to upload the book to the Google Drive folder so everyone can access it.
What is Git and why do we use it?

Git is a version control system that we use at Van Ons. All the projects we work on are stored in Git. It helps us manage and track changes to our code, making it easier to collaborate and maintain the integrity of our projects.
What are the main branches in Git?

The main branches we use are 'master' and 'develop'. The 'master' branch corresponds to the production environment at any given time. The 'develop' branch contains the most recent developments. When the 'develop' branch is ready to be deployed to a production environment, it is merged with the 'master' branch.
What are feature branches?

Feature branches are used to develop new features without disturbing the main code. These branches are created from the 'develop' branch and are merged back into it once the feature is complete. This allows us to track features easily and prevents conflicts during commit and push operations.
How should I name a feature branch?

For naming feature branches, we use the following standard: 'dev/[TICKET-123]'. For example, if you're working on a JIRA ticket with ticket number NY-18, you would name your branch 'dev/NY-18'. If there are no tickets for the project you're working on, use the standard 'dev/[name-of-feature]'. For example, if you're working on a product category page, you could name your branch 'dev/product-categories'.
What should I consider when writing a commit message?

When writing a commit message, you should ensure that the message clearly describes what you did and what part of the code you worked on. Consider what search terms you would use to find this commit in the future and include these terms in the message. The commit message should be written in English.
How should I format my commit message when working on a ticket?

When working on a ticket, start your commit message with the ticket number inside square brackets. For example, if the ticket number is NY-123, your commit message should look like this: '[NY-123] A very clear description of what I did'.
What if I'm working without a ticket or ticket number?

When working without a ticket number, start with the main subject (keyword) of your commit, followed by the description. For example, if you created a slider, your commit message could look like this: '[Slider] Homepage -> Created a customisable slider'. If you're fixing a bug, it could be: '[Fix] Homepage -> Slider -> Make sure next button triggers first slide after the last slide'.
Do you have any additional tips for writing commit messages?

Yes, one optional tip is to use a breadcrumb style commit message. This can make it easier for other developers to scan your commit message and detect keywords. For example: '[TICK-123] Page builder -> Related posts block -> Added an ACF option to add a subtitle'. However, the most important thing is to ensure that your commit messages are clear and informative, as described under 'General commit message rules'.
How do I set up a new project?

When setting up a new project, you need to follow several steps. These include installing the Starter Theme, creating a Buddy project, and setting up a development environment. Each step has detailed information that you can access by clicking on the links.
How do I pick up an existing project?

To pick up an existing project, you need to find the project in Buddy and pull it via SourceTree/GIT. You can check 1Password to find out what the development environment is. Check if there's a 'develop' branch present and switch to it if it exists. If not, create one. Most projects use the Starter Theme. If the project you're working on uses it, install the necessary packages following the README of the Starter Theme.
What are the best practices for using headings in HTML for SEO?

For SEO, follow these best practices for using headings in HTML: 1) Ensure there's only a single h1 per page, 2) Make sure there's always an h1 on each page, 3) Ensure all headings are editable by the client, 4) Don't use headings for styling purposes, and 5) Avoid using headings in elements that appear on multiple pages. Instead, use regular HTML elements like

or

and apply custom CSS classes for styling.
How can I improve my Google PageSpeed Insights score?

To improve your Google PageSpeed Insights score, refer to the Google PageSpeed Guide for WordPress websites. It provides tips and best practices on how to optimize your website's performance and increase its score.
What should I consider when setting up the URL structure for SEO?

For SEO, consider the following when setting up the URL structure: 1) Use 'nice permalinks' in WordPress, 2) Decide whether to include the category slug, a fixed prefix, or no prefix at all in the post single URL, and 3) Think about the URL structure before starting development. Collaborate with a project manager, developer, or the client to determine the best URL structure for the project.
What should I know about redirects for SEO?

For SEO, it's important to set up redirects when rebuilding an existing website. Ensure all old URLs redirect to the most relevant new URLs using 301 redirects. You can create these redirects in the WordPress admin using the Redirection plugin or ask your hosting provider to add them in the server configuration. Note that after a new website goes live, the client may experience a temporary drop in rankings, which should recover within 2-3 weeks.
What should I do before going live with a new website?

Before going live with a new website, you should always make a full backup of the old website, unless there is no old website. A full backup includes making a full database SQL export or dump and collecting all website files, including all uploaded images and other files.
Where should I save the backup?

You can save the backup on the physical VO Backup hard drive. This way, you don't have to store potentially large backups on your own computer, and everything is kept in one place. The VO Backup hard drive is currently located on Tristan's desk.
What should I know about using the VO Backup hard drive?

The VO Backup hard drive has a power cable and a USB cable. There's a USB to USB-C connector attached to it for MacBook Pro users. This connector is specifically for this hard drive, so please don't remove it. Also, check the README.txt file on the hard drive. It provides instructions on how and where to store your backup.
Why is it important to have good Google PageSpeed scores?

Good Google PageSpeed scores are important for several reasons. They can improve search engine rankings, enhance the user experience, and reflect positively on your portfolio. They also encourage continuous improvement in website development practices.
What should I do when optimizing a website for Google PageSpeed?

When optimizing a website for Google PageSpeed, it's important to document all the steps you've taken and the results. If you're unable to fix something, note down the reason why. Save this report in the project's Google Drive folder and include the date of the optimizations.
What are the three parts of this guide?

The guide is split into three parts: 1) Plugins to improve Google PageSpeed score, 2) Removing plugins to improve Google PageSpeed score, and 3) Development do's and don'ts to improve Google PageSpeed score.
What plugins can I use to improve Google PageSpeed score?
To improve Google PageSpeed scores, you can use plugins like WP Rocket for JavaScript and CSS optimization, WP Smush Pro and WebP Express for image optimization.
What should I do to improve Google PageSpeed score apart from using plugins?

Apart from using plugins, you can improve Google PageSpeed score by keeping the number of plugins as low as possible, testing the impact of plugins on the score by disabling them one-by-one, and replacing plugins with a negative impact with custom code in the Starter Theme.
What is the importance of good and efficient code for Google PageSpeed scores?

Good and efficient code is the foundation of a high Google PageSpeed score. It ensures optimal website performance, faster loading times, and better user experience, which are all crucial factors for achieving a high score.
What are some do's and don'ts for improving Google PageSpeed scores?

Some do's and don'ts for improving Google PageSpeed scores include reusing CSS, avoiding headings for styling, combining CSS and JavaScript files, minimizing external fonts, optimizing Foundation CSS and JS usage, lazy loading images, using appropriate image sizes, creating custom icon fonts, toggling classes, running 'npm run build' before deployment, limiting revisions, considering CDN usage, and optimizing WP_Query and get_posts usage.
What are some known issues that can lower Google PageSpeed scores?

Known issues that can lower Google PageSpeed scores include tracking scripts and pixels like Google Analytics, Google Tag Manager, and Facebook pixel, as well as running ads, such as Google Adsense. These elements can negatively impact the score even when optimized.
How can I contribute to improving this guide?

If you have suggestions, tips, tricks, or improvements for this guide, you can share them with the guide's creators or team members. Keeping up with the changes in Google PageSpeed tests is essential, and your input can help enhance the guide for everyone.
What is the approach of Van Ons when setting up a WordPress site?

Van Ons always starts from scratch, creating custom solutions for each site or app. They have established standards and agreements to ensure continuous development, collaborative work, and a consistent end-product experience for clients. They aim to use existing WordPress functionality in the same way and give custom work a logical place and operation.
What are the basic principles of Van Ons custom work?

The basic principles of Van Ons custom work include keeping existing technology, functionality, and structure intact, ensuring a neat handling of existing functionality, following the structure of the platform or software in custom work, and giving custom work a logical place. They also emphasize the importance of making the custom work understandable for a client 1 week, 1 year, and 5 years after delivery.
What is the file structure of custom work?
The file structure of custom work is set up in a way that when colleagues open a typical Van Ons project, they find a recognizable layout. This helps in maintaining consistency across projects.
What are Gutenberg Blocks?

Gutenberg Blocks are a part of the new editor in WordPress, named Gutenberg. They allow you to create content layouts, not just write text. They offer a lot of flexibility and can be used to build complex and beautiful layouts. This part of the guide seems to be a placeholder for further information about how Van Ons uses Gutenberg Blocks.
What are Custom Post Types (CPTs) and how does Van Ons use them?

Custom Post Types (CPTs) are a feature in WordPress that allows you to add your own data types. Van Ons uses CPTs extensively in their custom work. Instead of modifying standard Post Types, they create their own CPTs for each unique type of content. This makes the content management system more intuitive for clients, as each type of content has its own section in the WordPress dashboard.
What is the 'Theme Settings' in Van Ons' WordPress setup?

'Theme Settings' is a section in the WordPress dashboard where clients can manage site-wide settings that are not tied to a specific post or page. This could include things like choosing a color scheme or updating information that appears in the footer on every page. The 'Theme Settings' section is designed to be intuitive for clients, with clear field names that indicate what each setting controls.
When does Van Ons decide to create a plugin?

Van Ons decides to create a plugin when certain functionality is needed that is not tied to a specific theme and could work in other themes as well. This could include features like a dashboard or an upload tool in the WordPress backend. However, most of the custom functionality they create is placed in the theme of the site.
Why are you switching to SendGrid?

We're switching to SendGrid because it's as easy to use as Mandrill, but more cost-effective for our clients. Mandrill is a paid service that costs at least $35 per month, which is a lot for our clients who only send a few emails per month. With SendGrid, we can cover all aspects of a site, including working transactional emails, which is important to us.
What changes with SendGrid?

With SendGrid, clients will have their own accounts. Our project managers will ask clients to register with SendGrid, and we'll handle the setup. We'll also switch from the WP Mandrill plugin to WP Mail SMTP to connect with SendGrid. If you have any questions, you can ask Jelmer, Tom, or Dennis.
What if a site sends more than 100 emails per day?

SendGrid is free for up to 100 emails per day, which is sufficient for most of our clients. If a site sends more than that, the client can pay for it themselves in SendGrid, and we won't be involved. A subscription for 40,000 emails is $15 per month, which is still more affordable than Mandrill.
Why shouldn't we use the template override method in WooCommerce?

Using the template override method in WooCommerce can lead to several issues, such as making updates more time-consuming, having outdated templates, a higher chance of conflicts with other WooCommerce plugins, and a lack of overview of removed hooks. That's why we recommend using hooks instead.
What are the advantages of using hooks in WooCommerce?

Using hooks in WooCommerce offers several benefits, including no outdated templates, a better overview of actions that have been removed, added, or altered, easier updates, and more control over the customization process.
Can you provide an example of using hooks in a WooCommerce theme?

Sure! In the Procentec theme created by Van-Ons, there's a folder called /includes/woocommerce. This folder contains files for different parts of WooCommerce, where hooks are being removed, added, and altered. This approach allows for better organization and control over the customization of the single product template and other WooCommerce templates.
Where should I put HTML when building WordPress themes?

HTML should always go in template files, even if you need a function to echo or return HTML. In such cases, you should still put the HTML in a template file and include the file inside your function. You can use ob_start and ob_get_clean around the template file include when you need to return the HTML. It's important not to put HTML in strings or echo it directly in functions.
What if my function only returns a single line of HTML?

Even if your function only returns a single line of HTML, you should still use template files. If it's just a single line of HTML, you might want to reconsider why you're using a function for this in the first place. Consistency is key to preventing errors.
What's the difference between using template files and functions?

While you might see 'helper' functions in some WordPress themes that just return HTML, it's often better to use a template part and include that directly in another template file, rather than creating a function for it. This approach keeps your helpers file clean and your theme more structured. All HTML should belong in the template-parts and page-templates folders.
What is the vo_get_template_part function?

The vo_get_template_part function is a helper function in the Starter Theme that makes it easier and more reliable to include template parts with some arguments. It works similarly to the get_template_part WordPress function, but with the ability to pass arguments to the template part. This gives you more control over the data you need in your template part and makes it clearer for other developers what data is intended to be used in a template part.
How do I use the vo_get_template_part function?

To use the vo_get_template_part function and pass arguments, you would write something like this: vo_get_template_part('template-parts/post/description', null, ['description' => $description, 'children' => $child_pages, 'class' => 'page-description--short']). Then, in your template file, you can retrieve the arguments using the vo_get_arg function, like this: $description = vo_get_arg('description'); $children = vo_get_arg('children'); $class = vo_get_arg('class');
What is Turbolinks and why do we use it?

Turbolinks is a JavaScript library that makes navigating your web application faster. It works by automatically fetching the page, swapping in its <body>, and merging its <head> when you follow a link, all without incurring the cost of a full page load. This simulates a Single Page Application-like experience, improving the performance and user experience of your website.
What events does Turbolinks expose?

Turbolinks exposes a few events that you can add event listeners to. By default, we use the 'turbolinks:load' event to run our JavaScript code. This can be seen in the init.js file in our Starter Theme. These events allow you to run custom code when one of them is fired.
How does Turbolinks handle caching?

By default, Turbolinks caches every page visit. When visiting a page that has already been visited before, Turbolinks immediately shows the cached version while it fetches a fresh version from the server. When using the Back button, Turbolinks will only show the cached version. However, this behavior can be changed by setting the 'turbolinks-cache-control' header. At Van Ons, we use 'no-cache' by default to reduce the complexity of our JavaScript while still bringing significant (perceived) performance improvements.
What should I keep in mind when using the no-preview mode in Turbolinks?

When using the no-preview mode in Turbolinks, you need to be aware of a couple of things. First, cached pages might still have event listeners attached to elements on the page, which might result in unexpected behavior. To prevent this, you can either remove the event listeners from the elements using the 'turbolinks:before-cache' event, or attach your event listeners to the document object instead. Second, there's currently an issue with Turbolinks and autoplay HTML videos. The videos get cached when navigating away from the page and keep playing in the background. There's an open pull request on the Turbolinks repository to fix this bug, but a workaround is available in the meantime.
What is the VO Code Library?

The VO Code Library is a GIT repository used by Van-Ons to store reusable code. This can include a variety of code types, such as whole Gutenberg blocks, simple helper functions, plugin related code, REST API requests, and more. It's a resource for developers to both contribute to and utilize for their projects.
How can I contribute to the VO Code Library?

If you've written a piece of code that could be reused in future projects, you can contribute it to the VO Code Library. You should inform Daniël, Jesse, or Tristan that you have something to add. They will guide you on what to deliver, which typically includes the code itself, an explanation of what the code is for, and in some cases, a screenshot. Once all the required data is delivered, they will add it to the VO Code Library.
What should I do when I reuse code from the VO Code Library?

When you use code from the VO Code Library, it's important to double-check if it perfectly fits your project. You should remove any code you don't need and ensure to handle translations and other project-specific requirements. If you think you can improve the code, you should let Daniël, Jesse, or Tristan know so they can update the code snippet in the repository.
What is the Gutenberg Base CSS in the Starter Theme?

The Gutenberg Base CSS in the Starter Theme is a set of styles and settings used by Van-Ons to handle the styling of blocks in the_content();. It helps to manage the width and spacing of different blocks, and includes settings for block spacing, gutter, width, and more. It also categorizes styles into standard WordPress blocks and custom blocks.
How can I contribute to the Gutenberg Base CSS?

When you create a new block or modify an existing one, you can add or update the corresponding styles in the Gutenberg Base CSS. If it's a standard WordPress block, you should place it in the /wp folder and use the classname that WordPress provides as the filename. If it's a custom block you've created, you should add it to the /vo folder with the name of the block as the filename. After adding or updating the styles, you need to import the block in _gutenberg.scss. If you have any questions, you can ask Timo or Lex for help.
What are the settings available in the Gutenberg Base CSS?

The Gutenberg Base CSS in the Starter Theme provides several settings for styling blocks. These include 'block-spacing' for the space above and below the blocks, 'block-gutter' for the space between blocks, 'block-width' for the maximum width of a block, and 'block-width-wide' for the maximum width of a wide block. It also includes settings for custom colors, gradient colors, and font sizes that you've added via the vo_register_colors, vo_register_gradients, and vo_register_editor_font_sizes functions respectively.
What is the process for project kick-offs at Van-Ons?

At Van-Ons, the project kick-off process starts with a discussion based on the design of the application to be built. All elements are discussed and tickets are created based on the design. There are also functionalities or features not in the design but described in the Technical Design, which are also discussed and ticketed. The project manager or gatekeeper creates the JIRA tickets during the meeting. Each ticket should include everything that has been decided, an estimated number of hours for completion, and ideally a screenshot showing the part of the design which that ticket covers. The project manager is responsible for preparing and scheduling the kick-off meeting, creating the JIRA board, and ensuring everything in the design and Technical Design has been discussed and decided on. The gatekeeper is responsible for all technical and architectural decisions being made during the meeting. Developers are responsible for estimating the amount of hours needed for each ticket and helping the gatekeeper make the best possible decisions. Designers are responsible for clarifying decisions made in the design.
What are the responsibilities of the project manager during the kick-off?

The project manager at Van-Ons has several responsibilities during the project kick-off. They are responsible for preparing the kick-off meeting, which includes creating the JIRA board and scheduling the meeting before development starts. The meeting should be scheduled for 3 hours and all involved developers, designers, and the technical lead or another 'gatekeeper' should be invited. The project manager is also responsible for ensuring that everything in the design and Technical Design has been discussed and decided on.
What is the role of the gatekeeper in the project kick-off?

The gatekeeper at Van-Ons is responsible for all technical and architectural decisions being made during the project kick-off meeting. This includes deciding when to use and when not to use Gutenberg blocks, when to use archive versus page templates, preventing duplicate template parts or code logic, ensuring every element in the design has been thought through and ends up with a technical solution, and preventing dirty solutions, such as using WordPress core functionality for something they are not meant to be used for. These decisions should be made in consultation with the other developers, designers, and the project manager.
What are the responsibilities of the developers during the project kick-off?

Developers at Van-Ons have two main responsibilities during the project kick-off. They are responsible for estimating the amount of hours needed for each ticket. This helps in planning and resource allocation for the project. They are also responsible for helping the gatekeeper make the best possible decisions. This involves providing their technical expertise and insights during the discussion and decision-making process.
What are the responsibilities of the designers during the project kick-off?

Designers at Van-Ons are responsible for clarifying decisions made in the design during the project kick-off. This involves explaining the rationale behind design choices and providing insights into how the design elements contribute to the overall user experience and project objectives. Their input is crucial in ensuring that the technical team fully understands the design and can effectively translate it into a functional application.
What are the important server settings and permissions for hosting a Laravel application?

When hosting a Laravel application, ensure the following permissions are set up correctly: 1. The /storage folder and its contents should be writable by the Nginx/Apache user (e.g., www-data). 2. The /storage folder and its contents should also be writable by your SSH user, including files and folders created by the Nginx/Apache user. This allows you to run PHP artisan commands from SSH.
How do I set up Laravel queues with Supervisor?

To set up Laravel queues with Supervisor: 1. Install Supervisor on the server. 2. Ensure your SSH user has permission to execute Supervisor commands using sudo. 3. Make the Supervisor configuration folder (usually /etc/supervisor/conf.d/) writable by your SSH user. 4. Create a Supervisor configuration file in /etc/supervisor/conf.d/ with the appropriate settings. 5. Update and start the Supervisor job using 'sudo supervisorctl reread', 'sudo supervisorctl update', and 'sudo supervisorctl start laravel-queue:*' commands.
How do I set up the Laravel Scheduler?

To set up the Laravel Scheduler, create a cron job that runs the Scheduler every minute. You can use the following examples: 1. To log the output: '* * * * * cd /path/to/laravel/current && php artisan schedule:run >> /path/to/laravel/storage/logs/cron.log 2>&1'. 2. To ignore the output: '* * * * * cd /path/to/laravel/current && php artisan schedule:run >> /dev/null 2>&1'.
What commands should I run after deploying changes to a Laravel application?

After deploying changes to a Laravel application, run the following commands: 1. 'composer install' for PHP packages. 2. 'npm ci' and 'npm run prod' for JavaScript, CSS, and other assets. 3. 'php artisan migrate --force' for database updates. 4. 'php artisan view:clear', 'php artisan cache:clear', and 'php artisan config:cache' for clearing view, config, and other caching. 5. If applicable, run Laravel queue (mail) commands: 'sudo supervisorctl reread', 'sudo supervisorctl update', and 'sudo supervisorctl start laravel-queue:*'.
What are the usual requirements for hosting a Laravel application on Cloud.nl?

The usual requirements for hosting a Laravel application on Cloud.nl are: 1. Latest stable PHP version. 2. Phpredis extension. 3. Pdo_sqlite extension. 4. MySQL. 5. Supervisor. 6. Redis. Send your requirements to support@cloud.nl when you want to host a new site.
How do I fix an issue where the Laravel application is looking for a deleted service provider?

To fix the issue where the Laravel application is looking for a deleted service provider, delete the 'bootstrap/cache/config.php' file and run the 'composer dump-autoload' command. This will clear the cached config and autoload files that may still be referencing the deleted service provider.
Why is communication important in a team?

Communication is crucial in a team because if you don't communicate, it's as if it doesn't exist. If you find a great tool but don't share it, you're withholding a good find from the team. If you think code can be improved, are dissatisfied with something, or appreciate someone (give a compliment!), remember that no one can read your mind. If you don't say it, it doesn't exist.
How often should I communicate with colleagues and clients?

It's better to communicate too often than too little, both with colleagues and clients. Regularly ask yourself: 'Is the client informed?'. If a project manager is not available, send a short and clear email or call the client. Clients don't like being kept in the dark.
When should I communicate with clients?
It's always better to communicate in advance rather than afterwards, especially if it's bad news. A call can often make the difference between an angry client and a happy client.
How should I handle situations when I don't know something?

Clients see us as experts. If we don't know something, who will? Instead of saying 'I don't know', say 'I'll find out for you'. You can also say 'I'll discuss it with a colleague and get back to you'. Clients don't mind waiting as long as they feel confident that we will definitely solve it.
How should I communicate about additional costs or time requirements?

Never say 'it costs more money' or 'it takes more time'. A client always knows that it will cost more money/time, but they also need to arrange a budget internally or adjust a schedule. Indicate approximately how much time you will need (hours times rate). If necessary, involve a project manager.
What should I do when a customer is angry?

When a customer is angry, it's important how you handle the situation from that moment. Here are some steps to effectively de-escalate: 1. Listen to the customer fully to understand the actual problem. 2. Acknowledge the customer's feelings and show empathy. 3. Ask again what exactly the problem is, even if you think you know where the problem might be. 4. Summarize: 'I hear you saying that the site was down twice, but also that you can't do XYZ with the current site. Is that correct?' 5. Propose a solution and ask if this is the desired solution for the customer.
What are some tips for communicating with an angry customer?

Here are some tips for communicating with an angry customer: 1. Call them! People can hear your intentions and seriousness in your voice. 2. Focus on the outcome of the conversation. Aim to continue with the customer or the project in a constructive way. 3. Buy yourself time: if the customer is too emotional or if you simply don't have a solution yet, indicate that you understand the problem and when you will get back to them. 4. Only say that you understand the problem if you really do. If not, ask the necessary questions again. 5. Don't get too involved in the customer's emotions. Keep it businesslike and professional.
Why is giving and receiving feedback important?

Giving and receiving feedback can sometimes be difficult. Many people anticipate the other person's reaction (anger, sadness) and choose to do nothing because avoidance is easier than resolution. However, feedback should not be seen as positive or negative. It's a reflection of how someone experiences another's behavior or actions. It's not right or wrong, they are feelings. By giving feedback, the other person can improve.
Who should I give feedback to?
